title: Why Jay Leno Invests in Cars, Not Stocks
text:
NEARLY EVERYONE who lives in Los Angeles grumbles about driving there. The traffic. Enraged motorists. Torn-up highways. Not Jay Leno. The former “Tonight Show” host claims cruising its streets is a major selling point of the city.

“You have hundreds of miles to enjoy,” said Mr. Leno, 69, adding that you can bask in sunshine with the top down or drive a mere 40 minutes to throw a snowball in the mountains.

Mr. Leno’s fixation with wheels dates to his childhood in rural Massachusetts. By age 11 he’d already learned to fix a lawn mower. So when someone dumped a Renault 4CV wagon beside the road, he and some friends tinkered until they got it running. “We’d drive it around the backyard,” he said. “Mom would watch out the kitchen window. Today they‘d call child services.”

Share Your Thoughts What was the most surprising thing you learned from this interview?

Now with decades of experience wrenching, he has a collection that’s swelled to 187 cars and 163 motorcycles, which he rolls out on “Jay Leno’s Garage,” in its fifth season on CNBC.

Throughout his career, Mr. Leno also realized that cars were a good place to rehearse his comedy act, which he still takes on the road more than 200 days a year. “You need a place to repeat,” he said. “It’s a quiet room where no one’s judging you.”

Mr. Leno spoke to us about how a comedian’s mind works, the perks of riding shotgun and why he’ll never relax.

PASSING FANCIES Clockwise from far left: One of Jay Leno’s favorite artists to listen to while driving; Emma Thompson in ‘Late Night’; a Renault 4CV; In-N-Out burger; Dale Carnegie Photo: Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images, Getty Images, Alamy

People told me: I was crazy to pay $800,000 for a 1994 McLaren F1. The last offer I got for it was $17.5 million. I don’t know anything about stocks, but I collect stuff I like.

I like cars: that were noble failures, cars that were built ahead of their time. I look at it as kinetic artwork.

My garage: also has a full auto shop like you’d have at a car dealership. I’ve got all sorts of metal shapers and equipment, CNC machines and 3-D printers so you can make just about any part, even fenders. I’ve got guys that are experts who help me. I usually screw it up and then they’ll fix it.

When I drive, I listen to: a lot of Motown. I grew up in the 1960s, and I love Sam Cooke. But I also have a lot of really old cars that don’t have radios.

There’s nothing I like more than: eating in a moving car. I’m eating and going somewhere at the same time!

I’m not: the world’s most exotic eater. I mostly believe that there are five food groups: chicken, pizza, hamburgers, hot dogs and steak. Being a comic means late nights and eating when restaurants are closed, so most of my meals get served by people in paper hats.

I’ve never: been on vacation in my life. If I get a gig in Shanghai, my wife can poke around and I go to work. Jerry Seinfeld and I talk about this all the time: What happens if we went on vacation and found out we liked it? As soon as I slack off, that’s the beginning of the end.

It’s not that I can’t relax: I don’t want to. I’ll relax when I have my stroke. I’ve got a pool I’ve never been in. Well, I went in 28 years ago to fix the light.

When I do unwind: I go to a movie. I don’t like the superhero stuff, but I loved that Mindy Kaling movie “Late Night” with Emma Thompson. I thought it would do great [at the box office], but it flopped.

I find long-form TV: so much better than movies. I like the British cop shows, like “Happy Valley” and “Broadchurch,” which I stream on Britbox and Acorn. The women on there don’t look like Angie Dickinson. They can throw a punch.

I put a projection room: in my house 25 years ago, but I modernized it into a TV room. You have to keep updating as equipment gets smaller. It has an adequate sound system—I’m pretty easy to please.

I wear an Apple Watch, but: on stage, I don’t want something sending me emails. So I wear an IWC Repeater that chimes on the hour, the half-hour and 15 minutes. I like that it’s complicated—a real engineering feat. I also have a Jaeger-LeCoultre Duomètre Quantième Lunaire. People give me very nice watches as gifts.

The best gift I ever received was: a first-edition Samuel Johnson dictionary. I just find it fascinating. Whenever my wife and I have a disagreement, I show her the definition of wife as “chattel” and “property of a husband” and then she punches me in the face.

One book I’d recommend is: “The Perfectionists” by Simon Winchester. I enjoy biographies of engineers and people who’ve built things. I like “Equations of Motion” by William Milliken. He wrote it at 96 and was alive at the time of the Wright Brothers. It’s fascinating.

Life is: not that hard. It’s Dale Carnegie. Be honest. Accept your faults. Protect your troops.

I always tell people that: you should marry the person you wish you could have been. That’s a pretty good goal. The secret to a long marriage is realizing there’s nothing really worth fighting about.

I don’t have much use for: grooming products. I’m usually covered in transmission fluid.

Some of the comedians I like today are: Nate Bargatze, Neal Brennan, John Mulaney, Bill Burr, Wanda Sykes and Dave Chappelle. I like people who are good wordsmiths. I’m not shocked by bad language, I just get bored by it. To me it’s more fun to come up with creative wordplay that conjures up a disgusting visual.

Interviewing people taught me: to be a way better listener. Most people aren’t really listening and have no idea how to carry on a conversation. They’re waiting for people to stop talking so they can start. I’m generally interested in what people have to say. I’m not that interested in my side of the story.

The best comedy club in the world is: the Comedy and Magic Club in Hermosa Beach, Calif. I’ve done stand-up there every Sunday since 1978. It’s got a great mainstream audience—the kind of place where you can work a little bit blue, but you don’t have to be a gynecologist to follow the act.

Being a comedian is about: learning how to compartmentalize your brain. When you’re doing stand-up, you might see a guy in the audience and then think of a joke about him while you’re saying something else. But it appears so spontaneous.

I work in a business: that’s subjective. Some people think you suck, and some people think you’re great. The problem is, they’re both correct. But it’s different with a car: When you take something that’s broken and you make it run, no one can say you didn’t fix it. I work at night in my head trying to say things, and in the day I work putting things together. It’s a nice sense of balance.

—Edited from an interview by Marshall Heyman
description: For the ‘Jay Leno’s Garage’ host, there’s no time for trips, no room for boring cars and nothing like driving with a burger in his hand.
